A game, and not a fight.

I watch the world unmasked,
Edges softened by the dawn,
Questions gently asked.

The hush between the heartbeats grows;
I lean into the quiet sound,
Embracing wonder in my bones,
Letting memory come unbound.

For the first time, fear fades away,
Replaced by hope’s sweet urge,
A rush of sunlight through the soul
And tides that softly surge.

For the first time in my life,
I rise, I reach, I see—
The world is vast before my eyes
And possibility calls to me.

For the first time in my life,
I danced along a rain-slicked street,
Barefoot in a storm’s reprieve,
Awake within the heartbeat beat.

Raindrops stitched patterns on my brow,
Waves of laughter spilled out free,
No shadows clinging to me now;
Just the night, vast and wild as the sea.

I turned my face to falling skies,
Letting old doubts wash away—
For the first time, in my hungry eyes,
The world dared shimmer, bright as day.

With every step, a new delight—
The city’s hum, the thunder’s call—
For the first time, pure and light,
I danced, and dared to risk it all.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Low among shadows, caked in dust,
Bent by the weight of unspent suns,
And tethered by the shackle of must.

I kept to the cracks where the light barely fell,
Afraid of the hush and the gaze above me;
My voice was a whisper, my hope was a shell,
My dreams were a forest that swallowed the key.

Yet in the gloom, a hunger took hold,
To stand and to stretch, to reach and to roam;
From silence I borrowed a courage made bold,
And from dust I shaped a home.

Now upright I wander, a seeker, not prey—
For I was a grovelling creature once,
But I won't return that way.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Crawling through the mud of my own making,

Craving warmth with each humble, silent aching.

My back bent low beneath the gaze of others,

Too timid to lift my gaze to the wonder,
Too weak to kindle even the faintest fire.

But now, calloused hands grip the firm stone,
Shoulders square against the chill dawn air.
In rising, I’ve tasted life for my own.
From the mire, I learned how to care.

No longer do I crawl for crumbs or flattery’s glance—
I was a grovelling creature once, but now I dance.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the wind shapes the silence, and dreams seldom rest,
The earth holds its secrets in tawny embrace,
And the sun draws its lines on a weatherworn face.

Here the graying old homestead stands close to the sky,
A sentinel knowing the years passing by,
The paddocks stretch out, empty, golden, and wide,
Where only the magpies and wild cattle bide.

Evenings descend in a lavender sweep,
Echoing hoofbeats in distances deep;
Stars crowd the heavens, so vivid and near,
Brushing the shoulders of solitude here.

Yet hope somehow lingers in handfuls of seed,
In tracks of the horses, in slow, honest need,
On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Endurance and longing are never at rest.

Do tender spirits wake and roam,

Could draw me forth into the known

For through the shadows, ever free,
My heart returns, unerringly—
What stirs the world, stirs not in me,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Kindling the hush with a flicker of fire.

A soft-sighing perfumed invisible well.  
In gleaming repose the world seemed to be,

I seek Thee, God, in whispered prayer.  
My soul’s deep thirst, my spirit’s moan:  
O God! Thou art my God alone.  
No other refuge do I know,  
In storms I cling and onward go.  

Thy steadfast love my sole delight;  
With Thee, my soul takes fearless flight.  
To Thee I lift my eyes and see—  
O God, my God, abide with me.

Where wonder, trust, and longing be.  

Each star that glimmers, wind that roves,  
Each secret longing my heart knows—  
All gather in Thy boundless grace,  
My soul’s one home, Thy holy place.  

No lesser love, no fleeting fire—  
Could ever fill this trembling desire.  
O God! My heart, Thy sovereign throne;  
O God! Thou art my God alone.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A shade among the laughing crowd,

The longing held on silent wings.

Now, grown, I walk the winding road,
My heart a lantern, soft and thin,
And wear with pride the cloth I sewed
From childhood's hour I have not been.

War's a joke for me and you,
A shadow-puppet on the wall,
A story told at evening's blue,
When worries seem so small.

We jest, we learn, we shake our heads,
At others' pain and distant cries,
While safely tucked in feather beds,
We laugh at thunder in the skies.

Yet every jest is edged with pain,
A truth we never quite undo—
That laughter cannot cleanse the stain
Of what war's curse will put us through.

So let us speak our jokes with care,
Remembering the cost that's paid;
For somewhere, someone's nightmare air
Is filled with laughter we have made.

Passing rumor, myth, and news
Like candy wrappers, rain, or flowers.

Steel and smoke engulf the dawn,
But with a joke, we'll manage how
To gloss the blood, pretend it's gone.

We wear our armor made of words,
Polished with the news we hear,
And treat the war—absurd, absurd—
Like fiction fading year by year.

Yet every jest hides truth and pain,
A hurt the laughter can't undo,
For war—no matter how we feign—
Is never just a joke for you.

Here, we joke as shells pound

Humor becomes our iron shield,

But laughter, though it’s deftly wielded,
Is stamped with someone’s unseen pain.

Perhaps our wit will yet betray
How thin this peace is when reviewed.
War’s a joke—but only, say,

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
My soul, in silent shades, doth yearn  
For ways unseen, for heights unknown,  
To Thee, in quiet hope, I turn.  

When morning gilds the eastern skies,  
Thy light upon my face is cast;  
Within Thy holy peace I rise,  
Unshaken by the storm or blast.  

No voice but Thine can soothe my need,  
No hand but Thine can lead me through;  
Upon Thy word my heart shall feed,  
Refreshed, restored, and made anew.  

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
In night or noon, in joy or pain,  
I find my refuge at Thy throne,  
And there, beloved, I remain.

Before the daybreak fires the land,

And in the hush of dawn I stand,  
A pilgrim on the road of men.  

No promise holds my soul as true  
As whispered love from lips unseen.  
I thirst for living streams from You—  
The wellspring where my heart has been.  

So let me drink Thy sacred peace,  
My longing wrapped in praise and song:  
O God! My wandering soul’s release,  
My God, to whom I still belong.

A fire in His eyes, a cry unheard,

A beacon burning through the night.
With every truth His blade afforded,
He cut the lies the world supported.

For peace is more than calm and still—
It’s forged where sword meets stubborn will.

To wield the sword His truth declared.

Yet in that sorrow blooms a spark—of knowing, grief, and choice,
The echo of a world remade in every human voice.
We tell the tale in hopes to learn, yet in our own lives dwell,
Within the garden’s memory, and things we cannot quell.

A jest across the tangled wire,
Where boots and rain and bitter dew

So we, like clowns in tattered boots,

And grin at fate and empty suits
Who never watch the young men die.
For us, the joke is all that’s true—
We laugh because we cannot cry:
War’s a joke for me and you,
A punchline lost before goodbye.

Hair-raising novelty; lightning threads the dawn,
A tangle of anticipation where boundaries are withdrawn.
From the roots of each follicle, wonders tightly coil—
Humming with futures that shimmer and embroil.

It’s the scent of the storm before the thunder’s decree,
A gasp at the moment when eyes learn to see.
In the rawness of newness, every nerve alive—
We step on trembling thresholds, bristling to thrive.

Change, the wild sculptor, combs through staid routine,
Twisting the plain into something unseen.
Hair-raising novelty; thrill, terror, and glee—
All tangled together in possibility’s spree.

Fire: the first whisper of wildness in the night,
Quickening the hush and trembling the earth’s edge—
A reckless red flicker that dares to defy the dark,
Dancing on wind with a fevered, crackling touch.

In its heart: hunger—
The turning of branches to silvery ash,
The song of a thousand memories rising in smoke,
Warmed palms and wary glances, shadows cast and stretched.

Fire, the oldest storyteller,
A tongue of orange and gold that licks at fear and hope,
Circling, murmuring, promising light
Even as it threatens to consume the world it loves.

In every spark: a remembrance,
The power to build, to destroy, to remember—a destiny
Hung in the balance between fervor and grace,
Fire: the beginning, the end, and all that blazes in between.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Your golden reign has just begun.
You rattle shutters, stir the sheets,
Chase away clandestine feats.
Rings of fire behind my eyes—
Why must you so soon arise?
Let night’s curtain softly sway—
In darkness, dreams are left to play.
Chide me not for slumber’s grace,
For in your gaze, I must brace
To face the day’s relentless pace—
Yet still I beg, extend night’s space.
Oh Sun, reined wild through sky’s wide vault,
Let lovers linger—halt, just halt.
Your arrogance, our sleep has won:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Your golden fingers pull the night undone.
You burst through curtains, heedless, rude—

I plead for quiet shadows, stay—

Stay gentle, hush your eager fire,

So pause awhile beyond the pane,

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs,
its whistle carving new lines on the hush of dawn,
dreams pressed in the palms of those aboard.

Silence stirs, restless as shuffled tickets
and subdued laughter that falls like dew—
each window briefly framing hopes
hitching themselves to rails, to horizons.

All along the platform: shadows waving,
last glances tossed like coins into fate’s fountain.
The metal rhythm carries ambition and ache,
carriages inked with stories yet to start.

You can feel it—expectation trembling
in the dip of every passing telephone wire,
or the city’s pulse shrinking into distance,
while adventure rearranges the heart.

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs—
the hush dissolves beneath churning wheels,
a promise stitched in the thread of steel.

A sudden hum finds gentle hands,
cradling coffee, clutching suitcases and hearts,
while light tiptoes above the station roof
and plans are threaded through the moving dark.

Around each corner a world awaits;

each passenger’s gaze set on the vanishing horizon,
alert with hope, awake with possibility.

Why must you hurry in your flight,
Turning gentle dark to light?

Your brazen fingers tap my pane,
Igniting dust motes in my brain.
Yet in your glow my troubles flee:
You chase them off, though ruthlessly.

Relentless monarch of the sky,
You rule the world, you will not shy
From calling all to live anew.
O, grant us rest when night is through!

So march, old fool, sweep on your way—
But let us linger in the gray,
To steal a moment, dream, and run,
Before your reign has just begun.

Soft veils of dusk and dawn swirled overhead.

I wandered light, unsure of where to go,

In that first sleep, before the knowing,
My soul wandered fields unseen, unmeasured.
The world outside yet lay unflowing,
My mind untouched, my waking untreasured.

When I awoke, dawn painted my sight—
But in my first sleep, I danced with the night.

To climb once more toward love, toward grace.

O forlorn heart, so pure and unstained, yet so wary to commit,
Held captive by gentle doubts, you linger on the parapet—
A sentinel in twilight, watching loves pass down below,
Yearning for the sun’s embrace but fearful of the glow.

How bravely you withstand the winds that sing of ancient pain,
Your innocence a lantern as you wait in quiet rain.
Will courage blossom gently, or will shadows still persist?
Let longing write its verses on a soul that can’t resist.

instance_metrics.response:
I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side—  
They slide like lost travelers, swift on the skin,  
Each droplet a whisper of pain I can’t hide,  
Vanishing softly before they begin.  

No salt on my pillow, no proof that I grieve,  
Just echoes of longing that drift through the night.  
I turn to the darkness; it offers no leave,  
Just shadowy comfort, the gentlest light.  

The world keeps on spinning; my quiet heart aches,  
Invisible rivers I’m forced to confide,  
Emotions like rain that the warm pavement takes—  
I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side.

I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side—  
They drift down my cheeks and dissolve in the air,  
Lonely, they fall, with no moment to bide,  
Evaporating gently as if they’re not there.  

I reach for my sorrow, for proof I can hold,  
But the evidence leaves me with nothing inside.  
Soft, silent raindrops that vanish when told,  
I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side.  

My sadness is fleeting, like morning’s first dew,  
Invisible remnants of all I’ve denied.  
Unwitnessed moments I wish someone knew—  
I cry, but the tears don’t even stay by my side.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Between the quiet walls of night.
Outside, the moon hangs overhead,
Casting her dreams in silver light.

Her hands reach out for distant things—
A laughter vanished long ago,
The flutter of familiar wings,
A warmth that only hearts can know.

The clock intones its lonely tune,
A metronome for restless thought;
While shadows lengthen in the room,
She gathers solace, self-bespoke.

In silent hours, hope holds fast,
Weaving tomorrows from the past.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

She lies alone upon her bed,
The city’s hum her distant friend.
A flicker of the streetlight red
Washes her window, without end.

With eyelids closed she sails the streams
Of memory’s gentle, sorrowed tide,
Gleaning from all her scattered dreams
A hush the dark cannot divide.

She breathes the hush, she hears the beat
Of footsteps fading in the dawn—
But in her heart, the world’s still sweet;
She drifts, and never fully gone.

It finally snapped! A quiet thread
That bound my fears within my head,
A whisper trembled, brittle, small,
Uncoiling from a shadowed wall.

For years I stitched and patched the seams
Of brittle hopes and battered dreams,
But time, persistent, wore them thin—
And let the breaking-light rush in.

Now, fragments scatter on the floor—
The person that I was before
Has broken, yes, but see what starts:
A blooming from these shattered parts.

Not every fracture leaves a scar—
Some cracks reveal just who we are.

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Steel heart pulsing down the sleeping countryside.

Night-smoke curling where moonlit shadows hide.

The rails hum an ancient song of motion,

Each whistle’s cry stirs stillness like an ocean,
And distant stations wait, with secrets they can’t speak.

Onward pressing, past fields of velvet black,
Lamp-lit faces ghosted in reflection’s glass,
Time compressed and stretched along the endless track,
Between memory and hope, the endless minutes pass.

O journey’s arrow—ever swift, and ever parting,
Splitting shadow, carrying hearts that keep on starting.

Each phrase a fleeting shadow, each verse a ghostly lair.
Bow strung with longing, arrowhead of thrill,
My heart pursued the rhyme’s delight—I hunted words of skill.

At dusk, beneath a weary oak, I gathered what I caught:
A metaphor entwined in roots, a stanza overwrought.
Yet in the hush of afterglow, I wore a gentle grin—
For every word I failed to snare, was poetry within.

Yet hope in the shadows was born.

Skin frail as the moon's old shimmer,

Dreams rising from rivers grown thinner,
Souls fueled by survival and light.

Land cracked like a tongue telling stories,
Of loss, but also of song,
Of mothers whose arms, ever yearning,
Still teach the forgotten to be strong.

In the famine struck Africa’s morning,
Sun lifts the dark from the land,
Born not of plenty, but promise—
Still reaching for life with each hand.

Through me the path to sorrow's city winds,
A gate of shadows under leaden sky,
Where silence deeper than the night entwines
And every echo is a muffled cry.
Below my arch, the wayward heart resigns
The hope of dawn, of memory gone by;
Yet here, amid the dusk where torments start,
A quiet yearning stirs within the heart.

In ancient stone, regret and longing dwell,
Carved by lost souls who dreamed of light above.
The river’s flow recalls each tale to tell,
Its waters heavy with the weight of love.
Step gently, stranger—heed the tolling bell,
And let compassion guide you as you move.

Upon these words, "Per me si va nella citta dolente,"
A threshold of sorrow where shadows convene.
Beneath the archway, the air grows intent,
Heavy with stories that drift and careen.

Stones echo laments of centuries worn,
Tears pooled in hollows of cold ancient walls.
Each step through the gloom is a pathway forlorn,
A journey that memory constantly calls.

Yet sorrow is not without glimmer or flame:
In the cracks of despair, wildflowers appear.
A city of sadness knows also your name—
As you enter, you find hope lingers near.

Heartbeats, each shuddering, each alone.
The streets wind downward, silent, cold,
Past faceless windows wet with grief:
Here, burdens gather and tales are told
In hushed confessions, seeking relief.

Yet in this city of shadows and sighs,
A candle gutters beside each door,
Reminding wanderers who grieve and rise
That solace may flicker, gently restore.
Step through the threshold—let sorrow be known,
Within these walls, no one walks alone.

Still hope endures beneath relentless skies,  
For even sorrow’s waters yield their tears.  
  
So pass with care through archways stained and bent:  
Per me si va nella citta dolente.

How can you grieve and express loss?
Like waves that come quiet across the sand,
The ache rises gentle, neither bold nor grand.

We find a soft place for the hurting to belong.

Grief lives in the tremble behind your smile,
In tears that come after a little while,
In songs sung softly to quiet the pain.
This is how loss speaks, and speaks again.

How can you grieve and express loss?
Like autumn leaves let go, forlorn,
We are undone, and quietly tossed
In winds we never wished were born.

Silent sighs fill lonely halls,
Memories flicker in shades of grey;
Tears salt the stone that gently falls
From hope’s great arch, now worn away.

To grieve is to speak in the hush of night,
To find a language shaped by pain,
Yet in those words there lies a light—
A bridge that brings us home again.

Expressing loss is sharing care,
A weaving of absence into thread,
So even sorrow, placed with prayer,
Invites the love that never fled.

We sink into the dust, swirling as autumn leaves cast from trembling trees—
Lost in the hush where memory grieves and time is carried on invisible breeze.

The world above keens with color and sound, while below, we dissolve—
A slow unmaking, where earth and self silently evolve.

Yet, tiny roots seek what we comprised, and in the shadowed loam they find—
The echo of laughter, the salt of tears, what we surrendered and left behind.

In this dissolution, new promise writes:
We are never gone, only changed by countless rites.

The orchard shivered with the truth,

The world reborn out of lost youth,

Yet in undoing, roots remain—
A hope sown quietly in pain.

Cinderella is not the ash upon her gown,

Unfading beauty time cannot resign.
No prince, no glass, no gilded ballroom floor—
Define the heart her spirit offers more.

For beauty dwells in courage to forgive,
In hope that gives and gives and dares to live.
Cinderella—so much more than tale or name—
Is light that never dims, a steadfast flame.

As less on earth seek truth above,
A gentle hush invades the night;
The stars look down with ancient love
While mortals dream within their plight.

The whisper not of faith deferred,
But rather hearts grown faint, aloof;
Owls turn their heads—no longer stirred—
Searching the world for vanished proof.

Still, silver beams on rooftops lie,
Inviting all who dare to climb...
A promise glows within the sky,
Enduring, though ignored in time.

So let the few who look and yearn,
For meaning tossed on wind above,
Recall that, though the many turn,
There's truth for those who choose to love.

I told her that her two teams weren’t playing,
Yet something in her gaze said she already knew.
She traced the rim of her coffee cup, delaying
A reply, watching storm clouds drift through.

Outside, flags curled in a sullen wind,
Streets scattered with forgotten cheer.
Inside, memories of games that wouldn’t begin
Hung between us, trembling and unclear.

So we talked of neither victory nor defeat—
Just the pause where anticipation fades.
Her smile, a gentle hush, bittersweet,
As we lingered in silence, for the parade
Of colors and chants would wait for another day—
But together, we found our own way to play.

I told her that her two teams weren’t playing,
But still she wore her scarf of blue and red.
She laughed it off, the disappointment swaying
In stories of old matches, goals long dead.

We sat, hands curled round mugs to warm our day,
The radio silent, the streets calm and cold.
We spoke of heroes gone and dreams that stay,
Of rivalries, of banners proud and bold.

No final whistle sounded in our quiet room,
Yet joy bloomed up where banter used to be.
For sometimes love survives in every gloom,
Even when there’s no game on TV.
And so, from memories, hope took its shape—
Not every match needs a score to escape.

“In absence,” she sighed, “I quietly believe

I told her that her two teams weren’t playing—

We shared the quiet between cheers that would come,
Finding comfort in hush, and adjoining day’s end.
Games pause, but stories don’t leave us numb—
